[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Rust: Unsafe code] Does the underlying blst library use unsafe Rust that could have memory safety vulnerabilities affecting key operations? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Rust: Panic safety] Are all expect() and unwrap() calls properly justified, or could any panic during key operations leave the system in an inconsistent state? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Rust: Lifetime issues] Could any lifetime or borrowing issues cause keys to be used after free or create dangling references? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Rust: Integer overflow] While Rust checks for overflow in debug mode, could any unchecked arithmetic in release mode cause security issues? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Rust: Clone safety] The static_assertions checking Clone trait - if these assertions are removed or misconfigured, could private key cloning enable key theft? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [DoS: Expensive operations] Can an attacker force validators to perform expensive subgroup_check operations repeatedly by sending invalid keys? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [DoS: Memory allocation] Can an attacker cause excessive memory allocation through repeated key generation or aggregation operations? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [DoS: Deserialization complexity] Is there a computational complexity limit on deserialization that could be exploited for DoS attacks? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Rogue key: Negation attack] Can an attacker include the negation of an honest validator's public key in aggregation to cancel it out and forge multisignatures? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-core/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Rogue key: Linear combination] Can an attacker craft a public key as a linear combination of honest keys to forge aggregate signatures without knowing any private keys? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Rogue key: Proof-of-possession replay] Could an attacker replay a valid PoP from one context to another context where it shouldn't be valid? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Rogue key: Cross-scheme attack] Could a valid PoP from a different BLS scheme (e.g., min-sig instead of min-pk) be used maliciously? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Consensus: Key malleability] If public keys can be represented in multiple valid forms, could validators disagree on validator set membership causing forks? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Consensus: Non-deterministic derivation] If public key derivation from private keys is non-deterministic, could validators compute different PKs from the same SK? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Consensus: Aggregate key divergence] If aggregation is non-deterministic, could validators compute different aggregate keys from the same input PKs causing multisig verification failures? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Consensus: Serialization inconsistency] Could different serialization of the same key across validator versions cause validator set disagreements? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Validator: Key compromise] If a validator's private key is compromised, can an attacker sign arbitrary blocks without detection until slashing occurs? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Validator: Key rotation] Is there a safe mechanism to rotate validator keys, or would key rotation break existing multisignature aggregations? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Validator: Key backup] If validators backup private keys insecurely, could the serialization format make keys easier to extract from backups? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Validator: Multi-validator collusion] Could colluding validators pool their private keys to forge aggregate signatures on behalf of absent validators? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Deserialization: Point encoding] Does the deserialization properly handle both compressed and uncompressed point encodings, or could mixing formats cause issues? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Deserialization: Endianness] Is the byte order (big-endian vs little-endian) consistent across all platforms, or could cross-platform validators disagree on key values? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Deserialization: Error messages] Do deserialization errors leak information about why a key was invalid that could help attackers craft better attacks? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Forgery: Identity signatures] If a public key is the identity element, do all signatures verify as valid enabling complete authentication bypass? (Critical)
[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Forgery: Weak keys] Are there any weak public key values (beyond identity) that could enable easier signature forgery? (High)
